section.title: Search for entities
section.para: Where searching is available within a dataset (including the root), the osd:template will be present, providing an OpenSearch template which can be populated with query parameters. The most important parameters are described below for reference.

note.para: At present, there is not a well-supported mechanism for fully describing the search capabilities as Linked Open Data, although we are exploring possibilities in this area. In the meantime, applications will most likely need to hard-code behaviours relating to certain query parametersâ€”but where possible should do so based upon their presence within the OpenSearch template.

section.para: The q parameter is a free-text query field which can be used (often in combination with other parameters) to find entities whose name or description includes particular words.
The class parameter restricts the query to only those entities which are of the specified class (e.g., http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/Agent).
The media and type parameters are used to perform media-scoped queries: these restrict the results to entries which are indexed as having related media matching the given parameters.

The media parameter accepts either a URI within the DCMI Type Vocabulary, or one of the defined aliases: audio, collection, dataset, image, interactive, software, text and video, or the special value any.

note.para: Web pages and data views are themselves a kind of media which may be indexed by the platform, which may yield results which are initially confusing. The media=any query can be helpful for debugging, but has limited practical use in applications for this reason.

section.para: The type parameter restricts results to entries which have related media of the specified MIME type. Note that the broad class of MIME type may differ from the media kind described above; for example, a video playback web page is a video which has a MIME type of text/html. Generally applications will not need to expose this filter to end-users.

The for parameter expands the scope of the query, rather than restricts it: by default, a media query only includes results where the related media is available to general public; the for parameter causes the API to also include items whose related media is available only to the group of people identified by the specified URI. See Discover known audience group URIs for further details.
